quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Archimedes' Principle Calculations
quiz.subtitle: Unit 6, Quiz 3: Buoyancy and Submerged Objects
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: An object has a volume of 0.05 m³. When it is completely submerged in water (density = 1000 kg/m³), what is the buoyant force acting on it? (Use g = 9.8 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Buoyant force $F_B = \rho_{fluid} \cdot V_{submerged} \cdot g$. Here, $F_B = 1000 \cdot 0.05 \cdot 9.8 = 490\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A 2.0 kg block is weighted using a spring scale while submerged in water. If the scale reads 15 N, what is the magnitude of the buoyant force acting on the block? (Use g = 10 m/s² for weight)
questions.explanation: True weight $W = m \cdot g = 2.0 \cdot 10 = 20\text{ N}$. Apparent weight $W_{app} = W - F_B$. Therefore, $15 = 20 - F_B$, which means $F_B = 5\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A wooden block with a density of 700 kg/m³ floats in water (1000 kg/m³). What fraction of the block's volume is submerged?
questions.explanation: For a floating object, the fraction submerged is given by $\rho_{object} / \rho_{fluid}$. So, $700 / 1000 = 0.7$ or $70\%$.

questions.question: A metal crown weighs 25 N in air and 22 N when submerged in water. What is the volume of the crown? (Use g = 10 m/s², $\rho_{water}$ = 1000 kg/m³)
questions.explanation: $F_B = W_{air} - W_{water} = 25 - 22 = 3\text{ N}$. Since $F_B = \rho \cdot V \cdot g$, then $3 = 1000 \cdot V \cdot 10$. $V = 3 / 10000 = 0.0003\text{ m³}$.

questions.question: If an object is 25% submerged in a fluid with a density of 1200 kg/m³, what is the density of the object?
questions.explanation: Density of object = (Fraction submerged) $\cdot$ (Density of fluid). $\rho_{obj} = 0.25 \cdot 1200 = 300\text{ kg/m³}$.

questions.question: A 500 cm³ object is placed in a fluid. If the buoyant force is 4.0 N, and the object is fully submerged, what is the density of the fluid? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: First, convert volume to m³: $500\text{ cm³} = 0.0005\text{ m³}$. $F_B = \rho \cdot V \cdot g \rightarrow 4.0 = \rho \cdot 0.0005 \cdot 10$. $\rho = 4.0 / 0.005 = 800\text{ kg/m³}$.

questions.question: A boat displaces 5000 N of water. What is the mass of the boat?
questions.explanation: For a floating object, Weight = Buoyant Force. If it displaces 5000 N of water, the buoyant force is 5000 N, so the weight of the boat is 5000 N. Mass = Weight / g = $5000 / 10 = 500\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: An object of density 2500 kg/m³ is submerged in oil (800 kg/m³). If the object has a mass of 5 kg, what is the buoyant force? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Volume of object $V = m / \rho_{obj} = 5 / 2500 = 0.002\text{ m³}$. $F_B = \rho_{oil} \cdot V \cdot g = 800 \cdot 0.002 \cdot 10 = 16\text{ N}$.

questions.question: What happens to the buoyant force on a submerged submarine as it dives deeper into the ocean (assuming the water density is constant)?
questions.explanation: Since $F_B = \rho \cdot V \cdot g$, and none of these variables (density, submerged volume, or gravity) change with depth, the buoyant force remains constant.

questions.question: A balloon is filled with 10 m³ of helium (density 0.18 kg/m³). The surrounding air has a density of 1.29 kg/m³. What is the net upward force (lifting force) ignoring the balloon's skin? (g = 9.8 m/s²)
questions.explanation: $F_B = \rho_{air} \cdot V \cdot g = 1.29 \cdot 10 \cdot 9.8 = 126.42\text{ N}$. Weight of Helium $W_{He} = \rho_{He} \cdot V \cdot g = 0.18 \cdot 10 \cdot 9.8 = 17.64\text{ N}$. Net Force = $126.42 - 17.64 = 108.78\text{ N}$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You are very comfortable with buoyancy calculations.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! Watch your unit conversions (like cm³ to m³).
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing the formula $F_B = \rho V g$.
scoreMessages.0: Review the concept of apparent weight and displacement.
